[{'created': '2019-09-27 23:57:25.000000000', 'message': "Fix Ironic configuration for IPv6

When using IPv6 for provisioning baremtal nodes ironic.conf
needs:
  - [pxe]/ip_version must be set to '6'. Add parameter
    IronicIPXEIpVersion.
  - [deploy]/http_url must have the IPv6 address wrapped.
    Use the $NETWORK_uri value from hiera which carries
    an ip address fit for use in url.

commit_message:
Fix Ironic configuration for IPv6

When using IPv6 for provisioning baremtal nodes ironic.conf
needs:
  - [pxe]/ip_version must be set to '6'. Add parameter
    IronicIpVersion.
  - [deploy]/http_url must have the IPv6 address wrapped.
    Use the $NETWORK_uri value from hiera which carries
    an ip address fit for use in url.

Related-Bug: #1845746
Depends-On: Ib29adccc8378bd3e2a46b7d2ca3cfacba55e7674
Change-Id: I6384e11dd68cdbf2179545caae2c818fd1a6b23e

Sorry for late. I was checking the ideal solution, but it turns out we need some refactoring in horizon workflow code. It looks good as a workaround. 

I see the following problems in the current quota workflow with manila-ui integration.
- Cannot update the quota of manila
- Cannot retrieve the current quota of manila

This workaround fixes the first one, but the second one still remains.

I will investigate how to change the project quota workflow and horizon workflows codes with minimum impact (so that we can backport a fix hopefully)'}, {'account_id': 11880, 'date': '2019-10-01 16:35:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Cherry Picked

commit_message:
Remove the check which causes plugin's quotas update failure

The check causes external plugin's quotas fields unknown
exception because the quotas fields are not part of
QUOTA_FIELDS which only includes the fields for
cinder, neutron and nova.

Meanwhile the exception message throws TypeError.

This commit removes the uncessary check. It also helps
fix the manila-ui's bug #1842119

Change-Id: If093f4ecf1e344792b347c5c338b441b1ab42a04
Closes-bug: #1798048
Closes-bug: #1842119

commit_message:
Remove 'public' and 'private' parameters in fwaas_v2

The 'public' and 'private' parameters have been replaced
with 'share' and 'no-share' parameters in the Pike version,
they can be removed now.

Change-Id: I57a2e228ec1cdb6ed259914abc38bdada036d369

[{'created': '2019-09-26 15:00:18.000000000', 'message': 'Updated max-width to be dynamic for .member class

When member name is longer than $members-list-item-width
(130px) in members list (for example, project group in Edit
Project), current text-overflow will put ... (ellipsis) at
the end of the name and name will be truncated.

Updated the styling of .member class to make max-width
dynamic 80% and wrap the name in case it is really long.

Change-Id: Ic295a9b1e7fd3525c633d51a60054e713da6a657
Closes-bug: #1843480
(cherry picked from commit b635e625f75744938cde49fd250dd1a5f36ca1b7)
'}]
commit_message:
Updated max-width to be dynamic for .member class

When member name is longer than $members-list-item-width
(130px) in members list (for example, project group in Edit
Project), current text-overflow will put ... (ellipsis) at
the end of the name and name will be truncated.

Updated the styling of .member class to make max-width
dynamic 80% and wrap the name in case it is really long.

Change-Id: Ic295a9b1e7fd3525c633d51a60054e713da6a657
Closes-bug: #1843480
(cherry picked from commit b635e625f75744938cde49fd250dd1a5f36ca1b7)

commit_message:
[ceph-osd] Retry to create crush map for osd
while ceph-mon service down for a while.

This is update the logic to retry creating crush map for a osd if ceph-mon
service is down for a while.

Change-Id: Idffb189f0749a68a348cc0451daca5dec6796716

commit_message:
Add release note for bug 1845322

In change I0f9f75cba68e7582d32d4aab2f8f077b4360d386, we modified the
behavior of the ``--hint`` option for the ``boot`` command. We want to
backport this so add a release note to alert users to the change in
behavior.

Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Related-Bug: #1845322

[{'created': '2019-09-20 17:42:05.000000000', 'message': 'Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I3a1c2ca70c5c7f77f9e52a77dd3aac64cb46a9d1
'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I3a1c2ca70c5c7f77f9e52a77dd3aac64cb46a9d1

commit_message:
(actually) disable the inflight validations by default

- undercloud_config: set no_validations to True by default, since we want
  to disable them by default now.

  Introduce --inflight-validations in order to get those particular
  validations independently.

- tripleo_deploy (undercloud + standalone): add missing extra_args when
  running ansible.

Co-Authored-By: Cédric Jeaneret <cjeanner@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1843555
Change-Id: I95b8d7abc632b190ac6731393bd490bfa3aedcca

commit_message:
Never give up on resources

Configure pacemaker to never give up on resources and
to recheck 5 seconds after a failure. This is achieved
using migration-threshold and failure-timeout options *1.

*1 https://clusterlabs.org/pacemaker/doc/en-US/Pacemaker/1.1/html/Pacemaker_Explained/_failure_response.html

Change-Id: I4044810daa83f9bd7a59430b5c52c009149fac6e
Partial-Bug: #1839021

commit_message:
ec2: Move ec2utils functions to their callers

All of these functions only have a single caller now, so move them to
their calling site. Two functions are renamed to better fit their
purpose but there is otherwise no change in functionality.

Change-Id: I48237f306fb901dec9ec805704c891fd3cbb12e3
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I83b34c4c46a558898fd8dfb7d2939fbae526bb91

commit_message:
Fix LogicalSwitchPortUpdateEvent in Octavia provider driver

If port ovn_const.OVN_PORT_NAME_EXT_ID_KEY external_id is not
set we should return empty string for processing instead
None.

Change-Id: I815928e1a67e34c3aa577ee081541b67b2c43ddb
Closes-Bug: 1842901
(cherry picked from commit 5c174fe3d3f3b0c9ca1b23c2cc76b5063a3e9436)

subject: Proposed release schedule for Ussuri
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 7198, 'name': 'Jay Bryant', 'email': 'jungleboyj@electronicjungle.net', 'username': 'jsbryant'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 16643, 'name': 'Goutham Pacha Ravi', 'email': 'gouthampravi@gmail.com', 'username': 'gouthamr'}, {'_account_id': 17068, 'name': 'Jean-Philippe Evrard', 'email': 'openstack@a.spamming.party', 'username': 'evrardjp'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-09-03 16:45:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-09-03 16:46:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Just putting up as a strawman for now so we have something to review and look for major holiday conflicts, etc.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-09-06 10:35:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So, it's... likely that the Q2 event would happen early June, and in all cases I feel like we should leave much more room in the ussuri-2 timeframe (to account for both Christmas/NewYear and the Chinese newyear).

I'd suggest re-strawmaning with ussuri-2 on Feb 13, ussuri-3 on April 9, and final release on May 12."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-09-06 12:50:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

If we're not going to align to an event, wouldn't it be better to stick with a six month cycle to keep on a consistent and reasonable schedule?

Or make this one slightly longer, then make it six months after that point so future cycles better align?"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-09-09 08:46:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

In a few weeks we should have confirmation of when the next PTG happens, and for now I'd suggest keeping some rough alignment with that (so that the PTG happens near the beginning of the cycle).

In a few months we should have a clearer strategy for events in general for 2020-2021, and then I think we should have the discussion of whether decoupling the cycles and the PTGs make sense."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-09-16 14:57:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I have confirmation that we will have an event the week of June 8 where the development cycle planning activities (think PTG) will happen. It would be sad not to take advantage of that by placing it relatively early in the cycle.

I'd therefore suggest targeting final Ussuri release on May 12, with ussuri-1 on December 12, ussuri-2 on February 13 and ussuri-3 on April 9. That leaves 3 weeks between release and the event, for a 30-week cycle (2 weeks shorter than stein, three weeks longer than train)."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-09-16 15:08:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

That makes sense. This would also mean each milestone duration is:

U-1: 7 weeks
U-2: 9 weeks
U-3: 8 weeeks
Release: 5 weeks

I think that works really well with having a long period between U-1 and U-2 since the end of year holidays will basically mean 1-2 weeks of very low activity anyway.

I will get an update proposed for this.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-09-16 16:33:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-09-18 13:54:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Blind trust in Thierry. It looks okay.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-09-18 13:56:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-09-18 15:30:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-09-19 17:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-09-20 15:19:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

Ok with this at first sight, letting time for others to see this.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-09-23 08:34:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2019-09-25 17:30:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

There is a mismatch in the dates.  Not sure if it is intentional or not.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-09-25 17:40:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2019-09-26 22:28:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)

Hi Sean, thanks for uploading this! couple of questions inline - I'll propose a follow-up with Manila specific deadlines :)"}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-09-27 20:19:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-13 19:08:54.000000000', 'message': 'Use SpawnIsSynchronousFixture in reschedule functional tests

We see that in successful tests that are usually running some
kind of negative or reschedule scenario that they will dump
a stacktrace to the subunit output buffer because
_allocate_network_async will raise an error. Too many of these
can eventually blow up the subunit output buffer and cause
tests to fail.

To guard against this, we use the SpawnIsSynchronousFixture in
the base class of two known test classes [1][2] that show a
stacktace with _allocate_network_async in successful runs. As a
result, one of the tests has to be fixed due to improper stubbing.

[1] UnsupportedPortResourceRequestBasedSchedulingTest
[2] PortResourceRequestReSchedulingTest

Change-Id: Ib18ecaebbeccc9c9cea32ca8949175fcea0414ac
Related-Bug: #1813147
'}]
commit_message:
Use SpawnIsSynchronousFixture in reschedule functional tests

We see that in successful tests that are usually running some
kind of negative or reschedule scenario that they will dump
a stacktrace to the subunit output buffer because
_allocate_network_async will raise an error. Too many of these
can eventually blow up the subunit output buffer and cause
tests to fail.

To guard against this, we use the SpawnIsSynchronousFixture in
the base class of two known test classes [1][2] that show a
stacktace with _allocate_network_async in successful runs. As a
result, one of the tests has to be fixed due to improper stubbing.

[1] UnsupportedPortResourceRequestBasedSchedulingTest
[2] PortResourceRequestReSchedulingTest

Change-Id: Ib18ecaebbeccc9c9cea32ca8949175fcea0414ac
Related-Bug: #1813147

commit_message:
doc: Improve the document structure

This commit updates the document structure to fix
both HTML and PDF versions.
Some minor fixes are also included.

* doc/source/conf.py: Specify openany and oneside
  as extra class options for LaTeX.
* doc/source/conf.py: Specify the depth of TOC for PDF.
* Create a separate top page for "Archived Contents"
* Adjust the content of doc/source/contributor/index.rst
  to avoid unnecessary subsection.
* Drop strings from the top page as they leads to
  separate pages in the PDF file.
* Add "T.B.D." comments to placeholder documents.
* CONTRIBUTING.rst: Remove unnecessary markups for quoting texts.
* doc/source/parameters.rst: Update the mailing list link.

Story: 2006099
Task: 35137
Change-Id: I5fc03cd8ba53df58ee75e1c1bac4e906f840ec4e

networking-midonet train RC2

After RC1 release, a critical bug was found and the gate was broken
completely. This release incorporate it.

commit_message:
Add airship/apis project

- Apis will hold CRDs for Airship
- Storyboard is disabled, as it is not used anymore.
- Repository is to be filled along with CRD development, and at
the start will be empty.

Change-Id: Ica811b09fda9959fa14e3c395a84685d72140418

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as feature/graphql branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for feature/graphql

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as feature/graphql branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I214776a42f0d776d2755e4f4e4b5e5a78d0f774a

commit_message:
Remove ocata jobs from branch

This repo configures two ocata jobs to run as periodic jobs, these
need to be only in the stable/ocata and not in this branch - remove
them.

The stable/ocata branch has these jobs configured, so the jobs continue
to run - but the Zuul setup is simplified.

Change-Id: I57958f8388505aee5654f20c0c9c60f0e3ceea15
(cherry picked from commit 431ad460f85136fcad773818f3b12f3a17917b95)

commit_message:
Add bindep.txt to fix unit tests

The unit tests fail since no mysqladmin command is installed, add
bindep.txt to install the needed binaries in our CI environment.

Add also the usual bindep tox environment for developers.

Change-Id: Ie49b7703dbe5ebf66d9c0abd1bee830044f6b71b
(cherry picked from commit 5a978840f0c9550b8fa51f84c67c5649caf0ae37)

You will probably need to do some sudo configs modifications as it fails on running docker commands now.
According to https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/master/roles/run-tempest/tasks/main.yaml#L37 it is run as "tempest" user so this user should be able to do "docker" commands probably.'}, {'account_id': 4187, 'date': '2019-06-26 19:57:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 4187, 'date': '2019-06-26 19:59:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17: Workflow-1

I think the BGP scenario jobs have been failing because docker isn't being installed. There is a gate hook in neutron-dynamic-routing that handles installing it and sets up the apparmor policies appropriately. That doesn't exist here yet, so I added some ansible for the pre-run step to execute. This is patch set is the first step in working through this."}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-07-16 20:28:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Published edit on patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-07-16 20:32:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 19.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-07-17 07:30:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 20.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-07-17 10:13:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 21.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-07-17 20:13:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 22.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-07-18 07:23:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 23.'}, {'account_id': 4187, 'date': '2019-07-24 22:21:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 24.'}, {'account_id': 4187, 'date': '2019-07-24 22:24:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24: Workflow-1

Move neutron-dynamic-routing BGP tests from stadium

This is step 1 of the movement of the tempest plugin for
neutron-dynamic-routing.

Co-Authored-By: Slawek Kaplonski <skaplons@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I35984bb3ad3673b7a54982657c1ac6fdc3ed6de0

commit_message:
Remove ocata jobs from branch

This repo configures two ocata jobs to run as periodic jobs, these
need to be only in the stable/ocata and not in this branch - remove
them.

The stable/ocata branch has these jobs configured, so the jobs continue
to run - but the Zuul setup is simplified.

Change-Id: I57958f8388505aee5654f20c0c9c60f0e3ceea15
(cherry picked from commit 431ad460f85136fcad773818f3b12f3a17917b95)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-01 10:42:03.000000000', 'message': '[octavia] Add region-specific catalog lookups

octavia.conf is missing configuration values required to do service
catalog lookups in multiple region environments. Without them Octavia
can try to contact a service in a different region than its own. Specify
region_name and endpoint_type for the glance, neutron, and nova services
to prevent this from happening.

Change-Id: I753cf443c1506bbd7b69fc47e2e0a9b39857509c
Closes-Bug: #1841479
(cherry picked from commit 51033d9b3146267341f94d8a4c190623283898c6)
'}]
commit_message:
[octavia] Add region-specific catalog lookups

octavia.conf is missing configuration values required to do service
catalog lookups in multiple region environments. Without them Octavia
can try to contact a service in a different region than its own. Specify
region_name and endpoint_type for the glance, neutron, and nova services
to prevent this from happening.

Change-Id: I753cf443c1506bbd7b69fc47e2e0a9b39857509c
Closes-Bug: #1841479
(cherry picked from commit 51033d9b3146267341f94d8a4c190623283898c6)

subject: Honor OPENSTACK_ENDPOINT_TYPE in Horizon's local_settings.py
messages:
[{'account_id': 29820, 'date': '2019-01-18 10:20:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-01-18 10:20:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-01-18 16:02:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

commit_message:
NetApp SolidFire: Fix driver initialization

During innitialization, if a cluster is already paired, the driver
wouldn't initialized with an error.

Partial-bug: #1751932
Change-Id: I97df4f409f53b62d8a707656a767ee8baed959ec

commit_message:
Fix command-line options formatting

To render command-line options correctly, they should be quoted in
double backticks. This change fixes formatting for `new-release` command
options.

Change-Id: Iebbd2994d5ded61beb9f308656b7779482ce9d16

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Id76d05294606101c0dde373c1a51f7cae9c896fb
'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Id76d05294606101c0dde373c1a51f7cae9c896fb

commit_message:
Drop octaviav2 specific jobs

Since octaviav1 is retired, we need to make sure, that we're running
only octaviav2 scenarios and not v1. To simplify things let's assume
that octavia was always only v2, and leave v1 to lbaas.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/683594/
Change-Id: I270c0b623aef55bd6bf80b9bf5fdd618e4ced517

commit_message:
[WIP] Add a loadbalancer CRD

This commit adds repair CRD to Kuryr that contains informations about
service's annotations and endpoints' annotations, also there are some
changes in several files to ensure that CRD is created on the cluster
when using devstack.

TODOs
- Ensure CRD is created on the cluster when using devstack

Change-Id: I6bed08859880c4a0d8d0ca25aa648973f6266b63

commit_message:
Fix container configuration file path

The correct path should be hashed-container-startup-config-step_4.json
instead of hashed-docker-container-startup-config-step_4.json in
cleanup-dataplane.yml.

When this file was originally commited the path was
hashed-docker-container-startup-config-step_4.json but we have changed
it a few releases ago.

Change-Id: I901eedf64f7bd4281f94c156c33489355ff97aee
(cherry picked from commit ba55d6dbb8fd4e9d2cf91350b331c040c9c8f73e)

subject: remove winstackers team
messages:
[{'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-09-05 14:58:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-09-05 14:59:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 8543, 'date': '2019-09-06 06:56:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I'm part of the winstackers team and I'm trying to figure out which is the best way to move forward. I'd have a few questions about the process:

1. What happens to the team deliverables once the team is dissolved?
2. Do all official projects have to be associated with a team?
3. Who will be the one responsible of managing those projects, among other things being able to do releases?
4. Would a SIG or "leaderless project" help in our case?

Full disclosure: I've been working on Openstack for the last 6 years, trying to improve Windows compatibility. Claudiu Belu, the current PTL, is my colleague, sitting a few meters away from me. As the project matured and the need for development resources reduced, so did our team, yet we managed to actively maintain the projects and the CIs, as well as keep in touch with the community through the IRC channels, ML or ask pages.

What we didn't do so well is keeping up with the formalities. After a quick discussion with my team, I may step up for the PTL role if that's in our team's best interest.

As a side note, it's true that most of this effort is led by Cloudbase. At some point, we did get a significant amount of contributions from HP until that team got disbanded. As some people noted in the #openstack-tc discussion, Windows support may be one of the other teams' goals but it's not something that they can guarantee. For this reason, I think keeping the winstackers team could still provide value as it allowed us to efficiently do our work and interact with the community.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-09-06 09:21:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Lucian: I think there are two ways forward, considering that os-win is maintained by WinStackers and is a clear dependency for openstack projects.

A. stay the separate project team, with all the mandatory tasks like designating a PTL every 6 months

B. become a SIG, as running OpenStack on Windows is clearly considered a special interest

In case (B) you would keep your repositories and core teams, the only difference would be that you would push your tags directly rather than use the Release Management team releases repo, and you don;t have mandatory tasks anymore (like designating a PTL every 6 months).

os-win is a special case though. Since it's a library that a bunch of OpenStack projects depend on, it should still be released as a part of OpenStack. If we go with plan B, I'd recommend that it is adopted under the Oslo team (with the winstackers team as core)"}, {'account_id': 8543, 'date': '2019-09-10 08:51:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

It may be worth noting that Claudiu did candidate for the Train cycle: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/642244/'}, {'account_id': 8543, 'date': '2019-09-11 12:44:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

We, decided to keep the winstackers team, if that option is still available.

The projects associated with this team are indinspensable for the Openstack and Windows integration. The other teams may not be interested in adopting and maintaining those projects, which would be the case if we were to go with a SIG.

I'm willing to take the PTL role, offloading Claudiu from some of the work, whose main focus shifted to some other projects.

We apologize for missing the election. Despite that, we've been quite active recently and will continue to have a strong interest in supporting Openstack integration with Windows."}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-09-11 13:21:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote-1

Lucian has stood up to be winstackers PTL: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/681469/'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-09-16 13:29:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Sorry, this PR now: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/681491/'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-10-01 11:39:58.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Due to the fact that os-win is an oslo deliverable released by this team and integral part of the release, we have decided to continue winstackers as a team instead of a SIG. There is since then an appointment for the PTL role that was fullfilled.'}]

Following the U cycle election there was no candidate for the
winstackers team PTL role. This is the second cycle in a row where

in the community. This patch removes the team from TC governance, but

commit_message:
remove winstackers team

Following the U cycle election there was no candidate for the
winstackers team PTL role. This is the second cycle in a row where
that problem has occurred, which indicates that the team is not active
in the community. This patch removes the team from TC governance, but
does not deprecate the code they are managing.

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/tc/2019/tc.2019-09-05-14.00.log.html#l-148
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-September/009127.html

Change-Id: If17240dd1a523dffb341be8a606384547ceca86b
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

Blair', 'email': 'jim@acmegating.com', 'username': 'corvus'}, {'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 2903, 'name': 'Morgan Fainberg', 'email': 'morgan.fainberg@gmail.com', 'username': 'mdrnstm'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 6316, 'name': 'Anita Kuno', 'email': 'anteaya@anteaya.info', 'username': 'anteaya'}, {'_account_id': 7160, 'name': 'arkady kanevsky', 'email': 'akanevsk@redhat.com', 'username': 'arkady'}, {'_account_id': 8556, 'name': 'Ghanshyam', 'display_name': 'Ghanshyam Mann', 'email': 'gmann@ghanshyammann.com', 'username': 'ghanshyam'}, {'_account_id': 10607, 'name': 'Alexandra Settle', 'email': 'a.settle@outlook.com', 'username': 'asettle'}, {'_account_id': 14070, 'name': 'Eric Fried', 'email': 'openstack@fried.cc', 'username': 'efried'}, {'_account_id': 15334, 'name': 'Stephen Finucane', 'display_name': 'stephenfin', 'email': 'stephenfin@redhat.com', 'username': 'sfinucan'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23078, 'name': 'Jeremy Freudberg', 'email': 'jeremyfreudberg@gmail.com', 'username': 'jeremyfreudberg'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2019-08-21 20:51:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 20:54:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I think this will lead to a lot of unhappiness.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 20:56:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Specifically, I think a public preferential ranking of contributors solely on the merits of their names is unfair and will lead to bad feelings for those not nominated or who "lose" in the poll.'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2019-08-21 21:31:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 21:33:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

The update solves most of my objections, except that people whose names start with "T" may have to wait a very long time to be "honored" by this process.'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2019-08-21 21:41:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I cannot say at this point whether or not I agree with my own proposal.

I wrote this up with the intention of satisfying those who want  'meaningful'  release names but otherwise dislike the current process."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-21 22:53:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Love this idea!

But make it fully automated, not based on self-nomination.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-08-22 09:40:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

"OpenStack Freudberg" ? I think it is a bit weird to have a software release named after a contributor. I prefer the "large cities" option.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-08-22 14:00:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote-1'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2019-08-22 15:38:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

I slept on it and now declare that this proposal is my favorite. I really, really like that, under this proposal, release names will keep "telling the story of OpenStack" as they did under the current system based on the location of the summit.

There are some areas of the proposal to smooth out (like ATC vs any Individual Member, self-nominated versus fully-automated [and if fully-automated is overall preferred, some additional technical considerations are needed]). That said, I will not the update the patch now; instead of getting caught in the details, I will wait to see first if there is enough support in the community the mere idea of naming releases after people. (Sending mail to the list shortly to draw attention to this review.)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-08-22 16:07:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Not a fan of this at all.

- We already have mechanisms in place for recognizing outstanding contributors in our community. We don't need another one, especially one as arbitrary as this.

- Even if it's completely random, the use of an individual's name smacks slightly of the hero worship culture that's already far too prevalent in (F)OSS. OpenStack is designed by a community.

- It significantly diverges us from the previous release naming format. We can do that when we wrap but I don't think we should be doing so beforehand.

- It feels weird using a name meant for individuals to describe a bunch of code. I wouldn't like my name used for this purpose, personally."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-08-22 16:08:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-22 16:37:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

> We already have mechanisms in place for recognizing outstanding contributors in our community. We don't need another one, especially one as arbitrary as this.
> Even if it's completely random, the use of an individual's name smacks slightly of the hero worship culture that's already far too prevalent in (F)OSS. OpenStack is designed by a community.

Its very arbitrariness makes it not at all related to "recognizing outstanding" or "hero worship"'}, {'account_id': 7160, 'date': '2019-08-22 17:15:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Naming release after people is very bad idea.
It sets a very bad precedence, even if fully automated and unbiased.
It is the first step on the slippery road.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-08-22 18:01:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I really do not like this idea. I would in-fact dislike if a release was named after me. Cities are a little less..invasive. I worry that this becomes something that either is a battle/desire to get or a serious negative in the eyes of the person the release is named after.

Likewise I advocate against IRC nics or any other alias people go by for the same reasons.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-08-23 11:34:05.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-08-23 11:37:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote-1

> Not a fan of this at all.
 > 
 > - We already have mechanisms in place for recognizing outstanding
 > contributors in our community. We don't need another one,
 > especially one as arbitrary as this.
 > 
 > - Even if it's completely random, the use of an individual's name
 > smacks slightly of the hero worship culture that's already far too
 > prevalent in (F)OSS. OpenStack is designed by a community.
 > 
 > - It significantly diverges us from the previous release naming
 > format. We can do that when we wrap but I don't think we should be
 > doing so beforehand.
 > 
 > - It feels weird using a name meant for individuals to describe a
 > bunch of code. I wouldn't like my name used for this purpose,
 > personally.

+1 to these objections. Thanks for articulating it, Stephen."}, {'account_id': 6316, 'date': '2019-08-23 21:51:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I just see this getting nasty really quickly with no clean way to resolution.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-08-24 02:06:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-08-24 02:06:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> I think this will lead to a lot of unhappiness.

+1. True.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-08-29 11:15:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote-1

Some (most?) of our heroes are also humble and would exclude themselves from that process. I'm not sure we should optimize our contributor recognition process for those who would like to see their name permanently associated with a development cycle.

I feel like this option opens more cans of worms than it closes... My preference goes to as close as an objective, deterministic process as we can find, so I'll be -1 on this one."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-10-01 11:32:30.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This has too many dissenting votes, and didn't make it to the last round of propositions. Let's abandon this."}]

commit_message:
Fix an issue when nodes are not available in standalone test

When there is no node available, _try_to_associate_instance raises
which bypassed waiting.

Noticed here: https://1b623bcb8c866ffba3bc-dbe87819ad7b6716d83fae44185f9634.ssl.cf1.rackcdn.com/682029/1/gate/ironic-standalone/fc69fe9/job-output.txt

Change-Id: I7bcd804d3e01d80f977d428e6a084f4b7c7e1932

commit_message:
Send auth tokens for discovery

Some services authentication protect their discovery documents. Although
this is naughty, it's also reality. Since we have auth information,
override the Adapter default for authenticated_discovery to True. This
will mean any calls to get_endpoint_data will send a token, which increases
the chance they work, which is kind of important for microversions.

Story: 2006614
Task: 36803
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/685042
Change-Id: I809df055b6496dc60df2b721189a13af59468057

commit_message:
Add a non-voting ironic-inspector job

Both ironic and ironic-inspector rely on openstacksdk for x-project
communication. The ironic-inspector-tempest job covers accessing
ironic (from nova) and swift (from ironic and inspector). In Ussuri
we hope to start using openstacksdk for accessing glance, neutron
and cinder.

Change-Id: I42bf7d31dcb0a53006c6773c8f208b8b5c8bac12

commit_message:
Support vendor data in configdrive building

This change will allow a vendor_data dict to be supplied for
configdrive building, resulting in that data being written to the
vendor_data2.json file, which is what nova does[1] when building its
configdrive.

[1] https://www.madebymikal.com/nova-vendordata-deployment-an-excessively-detailed-guide/

Change-Id: I641a7d9e7214d0d4edbb9d9dd30b524fd282b242
Story: 2006597
Task: 36757

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-26 22:12:21.000000000', 'message': '[octavia] Add region-specific catalog lookups

octavia.conf is missing configuration values required to do service
catalog lookups in multiple region environments. Without them Octavia
can try to contact a service in a different region than its own. Specify
region_name and endpoint_type for the glance, neutron, and nova services
to prevent this from happening.

Change-Id: I753cf443c1506bbd7b69fc47e2e0a9b39857509c
Closes-Bug: #1841479
'}]
commit_message:
[octavia] Add region-specific catalog lookups

octavia.conf is missing configuration values required to do service
catalog lookups in multiple region environments. Without them Octavia
can try to contact a service in a different region than its own. Specify
region_name and endpoint_type for the glance, neutron, and nova services
to prevent this from happening.

Change-Id: I753cf443c1506bbd7b69fc47e2e0a9b39857509c
Closes-Bug: #1841479

commit_message:
Hide version 3.0.0 from Train release notes

The release notes for version 3.0.0 were displayed both on the Stein and
Train pages. Use earliest-version to hide them from the Train page.

Change-Id: I248430a9407d1944ae05ba2352b370862ef4e0e0

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1, 'name': 'James E. Blair', 'email': 'jim@acmegating.com', 'username': 'corvus'}, {'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 2903, 'name': 'Morgan Fainberg', 'email': 'morgan.fainberg@gmail.com', 'username': 'mdrnstm'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 8099, 'name': 'Graham Hayes', 'email': 'gr@ham.ie', 'username': 'graham'}, {'_account_id': 8556, 'name': 'Ghanshyam', 'display_name': 'Ghanshyam Mann', 'email': 'gmann@ghanshyammann.com', 'username': 'ghanshyam'}, {'_account_id': 10607, 'name': 'Alexandra Settle', 'email': 'a.settle@outlook.com', 'username': 'asettle'}, {'_account_id': 14070, 'name': 'Eric Fried', 'email': 'openstack@fried.cc', 'username': 'efried'}, {'_account_id': 15334, 'name': 'Stephen Finucane', 'display_name': 'stephenfin', 'email': 'stephenfin@redhat.com', 'username': 'sfinucan'}, {'_account_id': 17068, 'name': 'Jean-Philippe Evrard', 'email': 'openstack@a.spamming.party', 'username': 'evrardjp'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23078, 'name': 'Jeremy Freudberg', 'email': 'jeremyfreudberg@gmail.com', 'username': 'jeremyfreudberg'}]

[{'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 14:45:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-08-21 14:52:58.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from release-naming to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-21 15:18:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Cool idea, but there probably needs to be a veto process. My first swipe through 'V' included 'vasectomies'."}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 15:20:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Sorry, I should have marked this WIP -- we're waiting for a Zuul job to come back with a reduced set of candidates."}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 15:22:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-21 15:29:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> we're waiting for a Zuul job to come back with a reduced set of candidates.

Oh, is the intent to run the job, in zuul, just once, and then populate the list with whatever that turns up?

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/491e35babe734766a4ca44885c5d5aa1/log/job-output.txt#278"}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-08-21 15:39:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

In the current test run, there is already at least one, maybe 2 words I would not want to put in a TC certified poll, and others that are at best off the wall, and at worst don't look like actual words, so I am -1 on this approach"}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-08-21 15:40:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

Ditto. I don't think this has any meaning to it. Not to say that you need to have a meaning to the release names, but this just exacerbates the problem we already have - people getting distracted and wanting to do what they want."}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 16:11:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

To be clear, the *TC* would select these names.  You're not going to end up with something offensive.  This merely provides an arbitrary set to start with.  Pick "valentine" or "velocities" (or tweak this to support variants of the word and go with "velocity").'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 16:14:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 16:15:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

And if you don't like the set, we can run the RNG again."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-08-21 16:37:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Again, +0. Cities keep the geographical theme, while having the foundation choose names avoids the issue entirely. Both seem like better approaches than leaving it to a coin toss, of sorts'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-08-21 16:44:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Simple and works fine. I'd like to see explicit reasons to re-run the RNG outlined but generally this is a great direction to go."}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 18:58:53.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from naming6 to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 19:02:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Eric Fried wrote:

> Oh, is the intent to run the job, in zuul, just once, and then
> populate the list with whatever that turns up?
>
> https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/491e35babe734766a4ca44885
> c5d5aa1/log/job-output.txt#278

Yes, that is where the candidates in the current patch set came from.  You can see it's truly random; no human involvement up to this point.  The TC would select from those.  If we want, we can even do that now, and revise this with the results so that we only approve this with the final outcome."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-08-21 21:45:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

I actually quite like this one - obviously some of the random choices are alarmingly bad, but the TC is quite capable of picking on that isn't. I suspect that 10 is too small a number of options to pick from for some letters; 15-20 might be better. If this were the proposal for when we wrap back to 'A' then I would probably vote for it."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-08-22 09:27:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

One issue with this option is that we'd still need the Foundation to do a trademark pass. To take one of your list, if the TC selects 'Ziploc' for Z, that would clearly be a trademark issue."}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-08-22 09:41:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-08-22 09:41:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Returning my -1.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-08-22 14:07:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> if the TC selects 'Ziploc' for Z, that would clearly be a trademark issue.

That's not clear at all to me. Are Ziploc active in the field of computer software? (Spoiler: no. http://tmsearch.uspto.gov/bin/showfield?f=toc&state=4809%3Arlxweo.1.1&p_search=searchss&p_L=50&BackReference=&p_plural=yes&p_s_PARA1=&p_tagrepl%7E%3A=PARA1%24LD&expr=PARA1+AND+PARA2&p_s_PARA2=ziploc&p_tagrepl%7E%3A=PARA2%24COMB&p_op_ALL=AND&a_default=search&a_search=Submit+Query&a_search=Submit+Query)"}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2019-08-22 15:27:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Even if I get on board with the idea of using random words (not quite on board yet), I don't think the winning word should be chosen by the TC; I'd prefer it be chosen either by the community, or even better, not "chosen" at all... Generate only *one* candidate word at a time, and if it's appropriate, select it, otherwise keep generating one word at a time until arriving on an appropriate word.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-08-23 11:41:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

> Even if I get on board with the idea of using random words (not
 > quite on board yet), I don't think the winning word should be
 > chosen by the TC; I'd prefer it be chosen either by the community,
 > or even better, not "chosen" at all... Generate only *one*
 > candidate word at a time, and if it's appropriate, select it,
 > otherwise keep generating one word at a time until arriving on an
 > appropriate word.

I like that idea that nobody "chooses" the word. A word is auto-generated, checked for copywrite and other issues, and then is selected as the name of the release.

Of course we may have some push back against weird things like "this is the stop release" or something. It doesn't seem to indicate much. Perhaps we could be a little more distinct on what kind of word, it would have to be a verb or an adjective? (Not my suggestion, just an example)

Removing my -1 after thinking about this a bit more. I think with the suggestion of it literally being randomly chosen without any vote reduces the conflict considerably.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-08-25 06:43:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-08-26 10:53:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2019-08-26 13:02:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-08-29 11:59:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

+0 -- I like the objectivity of it, but I don't think random words are a good source for "good names". If the goal is to be random, I'd rather have a tool come up with totally imaginary words made up of common syllables -- that would likely spare us the trademark pass.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-09-17 02:23:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote-1

This didn't make the last round of our TC condorcet poll for how to handle the V-Z releases. Perhaps it may surface again during our discussions for what to do when we begin again at A."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-09-20 13:54:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote-1

This didn't make the last round of our TC condorcet poll for how to handle the V-Z releases. Perhaps it may surface again during our discussions for what to do when we begin again at A."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-10-01 10:02:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Even if I liked it, it's time to drop this. It has dissenting votes, and it's not representing what the tc has decided."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-10-01 10:02:16.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Name releases after random words

This process was an attempt to document as fair a process as possible,
but it has repeatedly not been followed to the detriment of the
project overall.  Moreover, due to our growing international
community, it is becoming more difficult to find appropriate names.

Use a random number generator to select a list of candidate words,
and ask the TC to choose among them.

Change-Id: Icf4281ec7e4f324e6c5a7e6e80f46267df52764e

I prefer the major city idea, personally, but so long as we continue to have names, those names are interesting and Foundation Staff are happy to take on the responsibility, so be it.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-08-21 16:43:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-21 14:44:55.000000000', 'message': 'Ask the Foundation to name releases

This process was an attempt to document as fair a process as possible,
but it has repeatedly not been followed to the detriment of the
project overall.  Moreover, due to our growing international
community, it is becoming more difficult to find appropriate names.

Change the process to be an internal deliberation within the staff
of the OpenStack Foundation.  They know our style, we trust them,
and the have the final call due to trademarks anyway.

Change-Id: I070a375255d520ff4f86ae1cbea89ce3b9134fbf
'}]
commit_message:
Ask the Foundation to name releases

This process was an attempt to document as fair a process as possible,
but it has repeatedly not been followed to the detriment of the
project overall.  Moreover, due to our growing international
community, it is becoming more difficult to find appropriate names.

Change the process to be an internal deliberation within the staff
of the OpenStack Foundation.  They know our style, we trust them,
and the have the final call due to trademarks anyway.

Change-Id: I070a375255d520ff4f86ae1cbea89ce3b9134fbf

messages:
[{'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 14:44:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-08-21 14:53:09.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from release-naming to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-21 15:02:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This works. Are we going to loop back around to 'alpha'? We would have a conflict when we get to 'kilo' :P"}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-08-21 15:45:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

for V->Z this could work quite well. 

Post Z, not as sure, but that is a longer discussion anyway'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-08-21 15:51:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Is it reasonable to respond with "meh". To me this should be the last solution if we seriously can't agree on a format.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-08-21 16:32:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm specifically +0. There's nothing wrong with this but we have the issue with things wrapping eventually, and it's rather uncreative. We can surely do better"}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-08-21 16:42:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

For wrapping do we move to duplicates, "Whiskey Whiskey" (for example) or increment the least significant so we have "Bravo Charlie" and then "Bravo Delta"? 

I also worry about "Alfa" as a name for the obvious homophone "Alpha", which would be a poor choice for a release name.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 20:06:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'd also just focus on this one as getting us to Z for now."}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-08-21 20:35:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Are we sure these names don't already have copyright conflicts already?"}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-08-22 02:23:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I'd also just focus on this one as getting us to Z for now.

That is a fair point. I still dislike this model compared to cities or random words."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-08-22 09:46:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I like the objectivity of it, but I prefer the large cities option.

While this works well until Z, I can see how "OpenStack Alpha" would be weird, "OpenStack Delta" a bit confusing, and we'd need to change again before "OpenStack Kilo". So I'd rather pick a model that will survive the post-Z era.'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2019-08-22 15:18:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This is an okay choice (neutral and easy) but we have other options out there which can be wrapped back around after Z and I'd like to avoid any possibility of needing to change the process twice."}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-08-22 19:44:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

I like this as an option to hold us over to Z.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-08-24 10:17:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I think we should do the election for name which involves the community. list of choice can be large or limited.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-08-29 11:51:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This is where gerrit fails us to debate complex options -- I think this would work well until Z but not beyond, but it is hard to express that in a vote.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-08-29 12:11:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

OK for going up to Z. I'd prefer to pick a system that would survive rollovers and avoid having that discussion ever again, but I don't think any of the options presented here really does."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-09-18 16:23:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

This was not the winner in our TC condorcet poll for selecting a system for U-Z.

We don't know what the winner was because it was a tie, but this was not it."}, {'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2019-09-18 19:55:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Practical. IMHO, I would do very well even without release-names, numbers are ok too.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-09-19 00:07:29.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review-1 by Morgan Fainberg <morgan.fainberg@gmail.com>
'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-09-19 11:24:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1 -Code-Review

Changing to rollcall -1 to reflect election results.'}, {'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2019-09-25 20:19:11.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review+1 by Sorin Sbarnea <ssbarnea@redhat.com>
'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-10-01 10:00:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

It was decided by the latest TC decision to either keep the current process or use major cities. This should be abandonned.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-10-01 10:00:13.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

This process was an attempt to document as fair a process as possible,
but it has repeatedly not been followed to the detriment of the
project overall.  Moreover, due to our growing international
community, it is becoming more difficult to find appropriate names.

Change the process to use the ICAO alphabet.  It is a neutral list

commit_message:
Name releases after the ICAO alphabet

This process was an attempt to document as fair a process as possible,
but it has repeatedly not been followed to the detriment of the
project overall.  Moreover, due to our growing international
community, it is becoming more difficult to find appropriate names.

Change the process to use the ICAO alphabet.  It is a neutral list
of words which start with each letter, and no more choices need
to be made.

Change-Id: I34d29a38ede7d7bac8221b40e91cc01e4eae8768

messages:
[{'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-11 16:56:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-11 17:00:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-11 17:35:23.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-08-11 17:41:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

I can get behind this. As the description which is being removed indicates, it was intended to be an enjoyable exercise to bring the community together. Over time it has evolved into a stress-inducing bureaucratic obligation which is divisive and unnecessarily burning out valuable contributors. It's dependent on too many outside factors (e.g., we can't even start gathering suggestions for the "V" cycle because the OSF is not yet able to announce a location for the conference happening early next year), and hampers progress on actual time-sensitive work like release planning and elections.

I know it's a community tradition, but not all traditions are worth preserving.'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-08-12 11:15:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

It is an interesting idea. 

A few things we should figure out:

* Where do we have a name assumed in our tooling?
* * Can this be migrated to a number easily?
* Do we want a combined "version" OpenStack?
* * Nova will be V20 in Train, and Designate V9 - how do we want to indicate what versions of OpenStack are co-developed, and have similar dependencies?'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-08-12 12:07:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Alternatively we can pick a random word from the dictionary and be done with it, so that it's not too much work for coordination in releases :)"}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-08-12 15:34:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> It is an interesting idea.
 > 
 > A few things we should figure out:
 > 
 > * Where do we have a name assumed in our tooling?

Off-hand, I'm aware of the releases repo and debtcollector. I believe one or both assumes that releases will be named in ascending alphabetical order for proper sorting too.

Maybe for simplicity we keep the letters but don't actually assign a name? That would be easier for the existing tooling to handle. I'm not sure what to do when we have to wrap though. I guess it wouldn't be a problem until we get back to U."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-12 15:50:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Word names should stay, even if they're picked arbitrarily or at random.

We could experiment with any number of other methods to gather candidates before just trashing the whole idea.

For example:

Anybody can propose any name for any reason as long as it meets the fundamental restrictions (first letter, length, legal characters, no profanity or trademarks, etc.). I.e. we're effectively just removing the "related to summit location" bit. Then the community votes. Worst case, this results in a really long list of candidates and a multi-way tie for first place, which can be broken by random selection.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-12 16:55:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Eric, that's a reasonable suggestion.  It's very similar to the current process, it basically just drops point (1) from the naming criteria.  But, given that the current process has no accomodation for vetting the names before the poll and it still happens anyway, it's not entirely clear to me that this would prevent that in the future.  Perhaps we could annotate the process with more text saying "no, really, the goal is to get lots of names, please do not reduce the list before the poll".

It could arguably reduce the tension around non-English words (the X release could have a Chinese name regardless of where the summit is held).'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-12 17:52:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> the current process has no accomodation for vetting the names before the poll and it still happens anyway, it's not entirely clear to me that this would prevent that in the future.

I think the key is that the current criteria make the pre-vetting process quite subjective. If we simply strike L23-5 and L83-7, the most subjective we get is arguing whether a word constitutes cussing or not.

Anyway, I'm not stuck on a particular process; I just don't want to see alphabetical names go away."}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-08-12 18:23:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think we need to maintain some sort of 'consistent' word to signify a collection of OpenStack releases (referencing to Graham's point)."}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-12 18:35:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Well, that's the thing, the current process shouldn't be especially subjective.  I didn't propose this because I thought the wrong call had been made on whether a single word qualified according to the release critera.  I proposed it because multiple names have been removed from the list for reasons which are not permitted according to the process (in addition to University, all of the GR names have been removed), and because this isn't the first time this has happened.

(See points 3, 4, and 5 for the relevant parts of the process: https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/release-naming.html#release-naming-process )

In short, the current process is supposed to be nearly as wide open as what Eric suggests, but names are still going missing before the poll goes out.  I'm just not convinced that the locality criterium is the only problem here.  I agree that the simplest solution is for the process to be just wide open and let people vote on a big pile of names.  But that's what the process is already supposed to be and it's not what we're doing.

If we followed the current process as documented, the poll would have something like 10 more entries, most of which clearly meet the criteria and were simply removed for other reasons.  So if we pursue Eric's proposal, I think we would need to get serious about that part of the process, the same as if we kept the status quo."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-08-12 18:46:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

IMHO, I'd rather we keep alphabetical names and instead stop arbitrarily removing otherwise valid name proposals before voting opens."}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-08-13 16:52:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

I suggest to say that we use an overall number - U is 21st release, so number 21 would be to use - as replacement. But I agree, we've grown and changed, it's time to change."}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-08-13 16:53:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Also, staying alphabetical is not possible anymore soon - we would reach Z and need a new resolution at that time and changes to our tooling if we wrap around...'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-08-13 19:37:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I do think it's a good time to start talking about alternative naming/versioning for when we hit the Z release. But to switch now would just be confusing and cause a lot of issues in a lot of different places where tooling and others things have been built with the assumption that alphabetically sorting will get the right order of releases.

Those assumptions definitely will need to change as we get closer to Z. But post-Z would be the natural point that we target for making changes to tooling and communicating to those interested what the new process will look like.

The only challenges I've seen that we've had with the current naming process is we haven't built it into our release schedule so we keep getting behind on coming up with the next name. If we would better plan for it and make sure it gets done earlier, there would be a lot less friction.

With the current process we will still run into issues like culturally insensitive names. Rather than scrapping the whole thing, I'd suggest we just come up with a better naming scheme for the next time around."}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-08-16 14:48:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Whilst I agree that there has been distress with the naming convention this time round, and in previous rounds, I don't think this is an excuse to throw in the towel at U.

1. Suddenly changing the pattern 8/10's through the alphabet is not exactly going to make it any clearer with our user base. We are the ones struggling with this, relatively arbitrary, issue and the users should not be subject to immediate change because we can't get our ducks in a row.
2. Eventually the alphabet ends, then we need to change. This is something we should be thinking about already as we only have 6 more (including U) releases before we hit Z. But this change should not occur now, this should be part of the forward planning proposed by the UC and the TC in conjunction with the community.

Like Sean and others, I suggest we come up with a better naming scheme rather than scrapping it in favour of numbers. Location and words are a big part of the uniqueness of OpenStack and we shouldn't so readily throw that away. We also need to be thinking of our user base, and not just our community-related problems."}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 14:41:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 14:41:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 14:41:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 14:41:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 14:41:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 14:43:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-08-21 14:44:48.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from release-naming to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 14:59:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Sorry, I accidentally pushed new patchsets on to this change.  I believe at the time, there were 2 +1s and 3 -1s.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-21 15:23:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

This is the only option (so far, of the five I'm aware of) that I'm thoroughly -1 on. It would be really sad if this group of diverse, intelligent people can't come up with a way to agree on release names."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-08-21 15:34:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-08-21 15:35:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Rollcall-Vote-1

I am -RC for the reasons outlined previously'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-08-21 15:38:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Rollcall-Vote-1

Moving to RC -1 for reasons above.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-08-21 16:30:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

> This is the only option (so far, of the five I'm aware of) that I'm
 > thoroughly -1 on. It would be really sad if this group of diverse,
 > intelligent people can't come up with a way to agree on release
 > names.

This ^"}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-08-21 16:34:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

Without some significant refinement i think our processes would break down by simply stopping naming.

I would be a fan of going to ubuntu year(num).month(num) style releases, but it would be the only option I'd support in lieu of naming. As it stands I am -1 on this."}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-08-21 19:50:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

I think a release name is an important way we communicate the collection of OpenStack project versions.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-08-21 21:30:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Rollcall-Vote-1

I agree with the feedback both here and on the list.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-08-22 09:31:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Rollcall-Vote-1

A codename is the clearest and least-confusing way to describe a collection of component versions.'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2019-08-22 15:02:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

Agree with Thierry'}, {'account_id': 28208, 'date': '2019-08-23 13:01:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

Android cancels naming of releases after sweets (lollypop, etc.); OpenWRT cancels naming of releases after alcoholic drinks (Whiskey, etc.); OpenStack, please, leave release naming. Thank you.'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2019-08-23 22:54:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

Agree with many of the points already mentioned.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-08-25 06:46:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Rollcall-Vote-1

I agree on all points here. It could have been best option if started from very first release and if we could have a single release model. With multiple release model it is difficult to get single number to all deliverables.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-08-26 10:43:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Rollcall-Vote-1

OpenStack 22, that happens to include Nova 21, Cinder 16, Neutron 16 sounds very unclear.'}, {'account_id': 28208, 'date': '2019-08-26 13:06:13.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review-1 by Roman Gorshunov <roman.gorshunov@att.com>
'}, {'account_id': 28026, 'date': '2019-08-26 20:10:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

Maybe instead of pure number, we could use number + alpha characters, so existing branches become 1A-1U, after we reach 1Z, we could use 2A, in this way, it looks different from pure number. And if we really want, we can still use code names.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-10-01 09:58:14.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This has too many dissenting votes, and we should not proceed ahead.'}]

Change the process to be an internal deliberation within the staff

'}, {'created': '2019-08-21 14:41:49.000000000', 'message': 'Clarify the existing release naming process

commit_message:
Stop naming releases

This process was an attempt to document as fair a process as possible,
but it has repeatedly not been followed to the detriment of the
project overall.  Moreover, due to our growing international
community, it is becoming more difficult to find appropriate names

These names are now more trouble than they are worth.  Let's stop
using them.

Change-Id: Iba6aa89b17492481d75580f373e1b835a9ed91c7

commit_message:
Add local bindep.txt

As it was announced [1] global bindep-fallback.txt was removed and now
projects need to have a local bindep.txt to be able to install binary
dependencies for testing.

In test jobs the script tools/test-setup.sh is called which requires
mysql and postgres servers and clients to be installed.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-June/007272.html

commit_message:
Fix fluentd and sensu images

1. fluentd on Ubuntu - pin faraday to <0.16

Rocky and earlier only.

Faraday 0.16.x depends on Ruby 2.3+, but td-agent on Ubuntu uses its own
old version of Ruby.

This change pins faraday in the Ubuntu and Debian fluentd images to
versions earlier than 0.16.

2. sensu-client: Pin minitest Ruby gem on CentOS

This was originally in change I1afd2d50c0dc2de6d305b56bd5f9182745fee843
on master and stable/stein.

(cherry picked from commit 305312f1070e80ba849f8c4feb00ad02196b8306)

Change-Id: Id9a76f459aff016fbc920370c0a3ec58e0397fcb
Closes-Bug: #1845647
Closes-Bug: #1845705
Closes-bug: #1845843
(cherry picked from commit a0712ceef3d6c20cdd79417dcff10525c527fb3d)

commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I806274d03b943e3253db6e9e78e84a8ece79e64d

commit_message:
Configure monasca-ui settings in Horizon dir

The default and preferred way of modifying the settings of Horizon
plugin is to add a configuration file to
openstack_dashboard/local/local_settings.d/ directory. For that to work
we should use the settings from django.conf.settings and not from
monitoring.config.local_settings.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/horizon/latest/configuration/settings.html

Story: 2006556
Task: 36645

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/682321
Change-Id: I718b51ce94b09bb547f03686831c3b1ac1721399

Andreas, the Airship 2.0 evolution officially uses JIRA to track stories among the community working across the UI, API definitions, and AirshipCTL.  This was decided at the Denver PTG and there was unanimous consensus. The open jira is at https://https://airship.atlassian.net/'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-09-27 18:09:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

alan, thanks for confirming. I'm fine either way - just checking this, I couldn't find it confirmed anywhere ;(

Just search for it at codesearch like http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=airship.atlassian.net&i=nope&files=&repos= or on the website ;(

And it conflicts with how *all* other repos are setup here. So, if there's such consensus, why is this not rolled out so that new contributors find it and reviewers sanity checking get no link?"}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-09-30 06:35:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 22477, 'date': '2019-09-30 13:50:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

I think part of the confusion is that, following discussion with the storyboard team, our long term goal would be to have some kind of synchronization between jira and storyboard such that either tool could be used.  However, in the meantime, I suppose it makes sense to disable Airship storyboard to avoid confusion.  Getting some jira onboarding documented is on our todo list - agree that that's important."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2019-10-01 09:18:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Fix tox.ini to correctly test lower-constraints

Due to the way we currently define install_command, all test targets
are using upper-constraints, including the lower-constraints one.
This patch fixes it and adds standard things like passing proxy settings.

Change-Id: I61c3b45ae591ea44688f29598cb8b802bb094423
(cherry picked from commit 91ed55678ee662df36794bf1f79153e6585023d6)

commit_message:
ng-6: Add new fields to nodegroup objects

Since each nodegroup will be one independent stack, we have to add
more fields to the table and object in order to track each stack
contained in the cluster. This adds the stack_id, version, status,
status_reason and version fields to the nodegroup object.

Change-Id: I6d36b2d3bc6476efbef6a9f702ffc73cfa0fab8c

subject: Propagate cloud_provider_enabled correctly
messages:
[{'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-09-20 15:20:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-09-20 15:29:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-09-20 15:35:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-09-20 15:42:45.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to cluster-user-trust'}, {'account_id': 16006, 'date': '2019-09-20 15:49:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Thats a good point, I've tried to somewhat documented the new behaviour."}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-09-20 16:04:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2019-09-23 02:40:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-09-23 06:33:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2019-09-24 08:57:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-09-24 09:01:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> (1 comment)

Previously, the computed cloud_provider_enabled label was being computed based on. cluster_user_trust in the config. However the computed cloud_provider_enabled was not being applied to extra_params[‘cloud_provider_enabled’] tag. This patch ensures that the computed cloud_provider_enabled tag is carried forward. Make sense?'}, {'account_id': 16006, 'date': '2019-09-24 11:20:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2019-09-24 19:12:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-10-01 09:12:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Cherry Picked

This patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/train as commit a7ca1fa3f0a13d19f35af5d1ca2b1365dd1d61d0'}]

commit_message:
Propagate cloud_provider_enabled correctly

The derived cloud_provider_enabled is placed inside extra_params so that
openstack-cloud-controller-manager gets applied correctly. This required
change was unfortulately missed in https://review.opendev.org/681922.

Additionally improve  the docs related to cloud_provider_enabled label.

Story: 2006531
Task: 36740

Change-Id: I4a89d25b467edd2c4be608c37055706e4e62d78b
